page.title: 07ECOLOGY IN WEST CAMBS.
page.content:
In recent years, many hedges have disappeared, victims of the trend towards intensive cereal farming and increased mechanisation. Farmers view this change as an economic necessity, but ecologists deplore the damage to wild-life. Some local residents feel that the removal of hedges has increased the problem of snow-drifts on minor roads in winter, and cyclists regret the loss of an effective wind-break.
Another practice arousing strong local feeling is stubble-burning. Many residents complain about the inconvenience from smoke and smuts, while farmers argue that, on heavy clay soils, stubble-burning is the only satisfactory method of disposing of waste straw.
